275FEC198E844CB2B4395EBF7FDC2456.description: Provide examples of how individuals and public and private Canadian institutions contribute to the sustainable stewardship of water through traditional knowledge and scientific and technological research and endeavours related to aquatic environments (e.g., marine research institutes, universities, federal and provincial government departments, and ecological groups) and identify possible careers related to the study and stewardship of water.

47D4629B1D2F478BA28AE627CD03152C.description: Describe examples of technologies used to assess water quality and how those technologies have changed overtime.

932F169857014368A65BC3BAB75B92BA.description: Identify strengths and weaknesses of different methods of collecting and displaying data about water quality.

84B299BE32F244F3B3CB48307E186EFD.description: Interpret patterns and trends in water quality data, and infer and explain relationships among the variables.

E60E69A3A7A74C3BBBF71796408340F6.description: Measure factors that provide indicators of water quality, such astemperature, turbidity, dissolved oxygen content, presence of nitrates or phosphates, and macroinvertebrates, from a variety of samples of water.

002802FB1A0247E3822636A851091799.description: Research a student-selected aquatic species, describe the characteristics of its environment, identify factors that could affect its productivity, and suggest methods of ensuring longterm viability of the species.

32A94EC520E243FA8EB5CBE37F307974.description: Identify factors that affect productivity and species distribution in aquatic environments (e.g., temperature, turbidity, sunlight, nutrients, salinity, water depth,currents, overfishing, upwelling, and pollutants).

8761CF00564F4A30B496E6A392D5C909.description: Identify diverse examples of organisms in a variety of marine and freshwater ecosystems (e.g., wetlands, lakes, rivers, salt marsh, estuary, ocean, and intertidal zone) and explain how biodiversity is an indicator of ecosystem health.

03858B48E16A4CF99433BEC8CC5B48C3.description: Examine the ways in which First Nations and Métis people traditionally valued, depended upon, and cared for aquatic wildlife and plants in Saskatchewan and Canada.

BB59A506F5CD49248C037B875B73441D.description: Analyze natural factors and human practices that affect productivity and species distribution in marine and fresh water environments.

47889A33EA5248A9958E6C568CBEB7AD.description: Propose new questions and problems for future study that arise from the study of the effects of wind, water, and ice on the landscape (e.g., “How might changes in glaciers affect Saskatchewan water supplies?”“How might icecap melting change Canadian coastlines?”).

11954F90CE6C495D9C795AF85A9E0336.description: Identify factors that affect polar icecap formation and reduction and their effects on the environment, including possible changes to ocean currents and climate patterns.

9E6F08B11AE0463C897A67A82A7008D0.description: Relate factors that affect glacier formation and reduction and their effects on the environment to the formation of glacial landforms in Saskatchewan (e.g., drumlins, moraines, eskers, and kettle lakes).

F79D3A4FC5B546FC810B577D076D382F.description: Create a written, visual, physical, or dramatic representation of the processes that lead to the development of rivers, lakes, continental drainage systems, and ocean basins, including glaciation, continental drift, erosion, and volcanic action.

27831FC533C24D6D938270CCBCA79880.description: Critique the design and function of technologies designed to minimize damage due to waves and tides (e.g., piers, breakwaters, dune vegetation, and coastline reconfiguration) in oceans and in-land water bodies.

B5AA93BE6A22404A827611E6F204739F.description: Describe how the interactions of ocean currents, winds, and regional climates shape local, regional, national, and global environments.

26E5C49CC60748578420E67BCDA47FF4.description: Explain the meaning and significance of the forces thatshape the landscape to First Nations and Métis people.

9BDE2436BF0E42AEAC25986A1ED0BAE5.description: Plan and conduct a simulation to demonstrate how temperature differences cause water currents.

72725519A89C46E7A5DE37667721DC9E.description: Explain how the processes of weathering, erosion, and deposition result from water movement and wave action, including how waves and tides are generated and howthey interact with shorelines.

D72465E5599D4EAA9991CA31584A4789.description: Examine how wind, water, and ice have shaped and continue to shape the Canadian landscape.

A6350192161A4AADAD00463A62919EF8.description: Evaluate individual and group processes used inplanning, problem solving, decision making, and completing a task related to studying threats to water systems, such as accepting various roles in a group, sharing responsibility for carrying out decisions, and seeking consensus before making decisions.

54C2AA13B0124AB48B11813FBFB241F6.description: Research a specific human practice or technology that may pose a threat to surface and/or groundwater systems in Saskatchewan and explain how different groups in society (e.g., landowner, consumer, business owner, recreational user, fisherman, government official, and farmer) may have conflicting needs and desires in relation to the practice or technology and how those decisions or actions of different stakeholders may or may not be addressed by scientific or technological knowledge.

3611360A47744B6199A2BE2238B82227.description: Identify possible personal, societal, economic, and environmental consequences of natural changes and human practices and technologies that pose threats to surface and/ or ground water systems in Saskatchewan (e.g., vegetation removal, water and sewage treatment plants, timber harvesting, over-application of fertilizers, agricultural and urban irrigation, impervious ground cover, land alterations, mining, introduction of invasive species, shoreline erosion, fluctuating lake levels, flooding, draining and/or channelling of surface water features, and damming of rivers).

E50A782B9F9D47109117A82C926BF9FB.description: Construct a written, visual, or dramatic representation ofthe water cycle, including showing or explaining how a single particle of water can travel through the cycle over extended periods of time

D57CB75EFBB24E60930BC0091BD95A74.description: Apply the concept of systems as a tool for interpreting the structure and interactions of water systems by constructing representations of systems such as the water cycle, watersheds, and continental drainage basins and showing interrelationships between parts of the system.

F934701949444354816B8E346A847027.description: Examine the significance of water to First Nations and Métis people of Saskatchewan, including water as an essential element of life, transportation, water quality, fishingpractices, and treaty rights regarding fishing.

B2473701E994449F9017ECB8AB04DEE8.description: Compare physical characteristics of surface waterfeatures, such as lakes, rivers, streams, wetlands, and riparianareas

54B03A3D4FF2445C9408BA89F58F0229.description: Construct visual representations of the world distribution of water, and the distribution of water in Saskatchewan, including watersheds, lakes, rivers, streams, riversystems, wetlands, ground water, saline lakes, and riparian areas.

0EFCB7CF1911462A94F757AC8CFBB89F.description: Analyze the impact of natural and human-induced changes to the characteristics and distribution of water in local, regional, and national ecosystems.

40B72972A2A94E5B83DD02C4AAE44C10.description: Earth and Space Science: Water Systems on Earth (WS)

9D8C78C5B67D45E4A1A65E45C4628DB0.description: Provide examples of Canadian contributions to the science and technology of fluids (e.g., submersibles, oil rigs and platforms, diving equipment, pumps, tires, and vacuum cleaners).

F9938E59319C4B849B681C09B8015C97.description: Describe and explain the role of collecting evidence, finding relationships, proposing explanations, and imagination inthe development of scientific knowledge related to fluids and fluid systems (e.g., finding relationships between density or pressure and change in temperature provides insights into practical uses for fluids).

3E8851A69AC04CD588A584E54BE5F173.description: Apply given criteria for evaluating evidence and sources of information by testing a prototype of a natural or constructed fluid system in a variety of situations to ensure that the results were not due to chance.

28EDC0AD762B4B73A6169704D58CBDF8.description: Work collaboratively to identify and correct problems inthe way a prototype of a natural or constructed fluid system functions.

E02C923CF2D04B86A41BF2396132E15E.description: Use a technological problem-solving process to design, construct, and evaluate a prototype of a device that models the operation of a natural or constructed fluid system.

06F4232D0B2F4874982811CE26B00EDA.description: Compare natural (e.g., circulatory and respiratorysystem) and constructed (e.g., hydraulic and air brakes, oil and gas pipelines, swimming pool circulation system, bicycle and other pumps, Archimedes screw, and automobile lifts) hydraulic and pneumatic fluid systems and identify advantages and disadvantages of each, using studentidentified criteria such as cost and impact on society and the environment.

4D5E59F72CD247F1A7C0F0315AAB327E.description: Describe how hydraulic or pneumatic pressure can be usedto create a mechanical advantage in a simple mechanical device (e.g., hydraulic jack, air powered tools, hairstylist’s chair, and water spraying toy)

6F9A9E494E4A4DDDBC8DCA736633B5DC.description: Identify and interpret the scientific principles underlying the functioning of natural and constructed fluid systems.

04FD29D7DB4E43B59831732D8736960B.description: Show concern for safety of self and others when planning, carrying out, and reviewing procedures involving heatingand compressing liquids and gases.

1FCF1E7E0D7C46EAAF0A80EA78717871.description: Explore and explain qualitatively the relationship between pressure, volume, and temperature when liquids andgases are compressed or heated.

29F3FA16AD964DA29E5DA47284258BB5.description: Use the particle theory of matter to explain the differencesin compressibility between liquids and gases

9CB6F697D504449E90598125BD3A47D7.description: Describe situations in which pressure can be increased or decreased by altering surface area (e.g., snowshoes vs. boots, flat-heeled vs. high-heeled shoes, adaptive hoof shape of the woodland caribou, dual or triple tires on a tractor, andplacing a thumb over the end of a garden hose).

355EFF0B00B44137B28487E154A5AC10.description: Predict and investigate the effect of applying external pressure to the behaviour of liquids and gases (e.g., squeezing a balloon, depressing a plunger in a syringe).

BBF6B638ADB448B0974327FE1863A886.description: Identify products in which viscosity is an important property (e.g., paint, hand lotion, motor oil, salad dressing, and condiments) and evaluate different brands of thoseproducts using student-developed criteria.

446EEE471BA1426D9BF6C4E50A084817.description: Use a temperature measuring technology, such as a temperature probe, effectively and accurately for collecting data to investigate the relationship between temperatureand viscosity of a liquid.

BB7AFBBA19534CCAAD9471FA2784E4FE.description: Investigate the relationship between the temperatureand viscosity of a liquid, controlling the major variables.

E2EA1ED62ED3404A8A346B053ED0038D.description: Demonstrate knowledge of Workplace HazardousMaterials Information System (WHMIS) standards by using proper techniques for handling and disposing of lab materials and by explaining the WHMIS labelling system.

D667C84C2B6D404DB82C31256C86872A.description: Use appropriate vocabulary related to the study of fluids, including fluid, viscosity, buoyancy, pressure, compressibility, hydraulic, pneumatic, and density.

DCDBB4F0B9974E8295D983B9D9B953A7.description: Design and conduct an experiment to compare the viscosity of various fluids (e.g., water, syrup, oil, shampoo, glycerine, honey, ketchup, hand cream, and detergent) and identify variables relevant to the investigation

3B4A686E95874444A1AB5E3ECAB6339D.description: Investigate and describe physical properties of fluids (liquids and gases), including viscosity and compressibility

B3D7196118F447319BA0A66B6152F141.description: Analyze designs of traditional and contemporarywatercraft (e.g., canoe, kayak, lake boat, catamaran, and jet-ski) with respect to the principles of buoyancy.

D17C66E998D1411087D0D763B779D3E3.description: Explain the operation of technologies whose developmentis based on scientific understanding of the properties of fluids (e.g., personal flotation devices, float planes, surfboards, gliders, anti-freeze tester, and heart pumps).

07020B05ACE44F4DB227729F78578CE7.description: Compare different fluids to determine how they alterthe buoyant force on a given object.

BD0F8D4970F64FC39EE9A6B6A06B3065.description: Use a technological problem-solving process to design, construct, and evaluate a prototype of an object that floats and can carry the greatest amount of cargo.

E8814576A28C42228051F4372138FC4B.description: Use a technological problem-solving process to design, construct, and evaluate a prototype of an object that floats and can carry the greatest amount of cargo.

C9D82D6609EF4EE1A66247B32007E9A8.description: Conduct a fair test to identify which factors determine whether a given object will float or sink, and discuss reasons why scientists control some variables when conducting a fair test.

C14FCDBEEF0F4031859B1924AB3801B8.description: Express the quantitative relationship between pressure,force, and area in fluids.

C562B50062C349BE893B8D874F6C7B20.description: Use a spring scale to determine the relationship between mass and weight for various substances.

07F15D606BB7423BA4571C666DF64E73.description: Illustrate, using force diagrams, the movement of objects in fluids in terms of balanced and unbalanced forces acting on the objects.

1F91D0D2F7D8444BACD4425490E2134B.description: Explain the concept of force and provide examplesof different types of contact and non-contact forces.

B9DCE1C424DE49D78A0697E699515899.description: Examine contributions of people from various cultures to understanding the principles of buoyancy, including Archimedes Principle, and the development of watercraft such as canoes and kayaks.

3E72DECD163543CFB7E86A374A6E5965.description: Identify questions to investigate arising from practical problems and issues involving floating, sinking, and buoyancy (e.g., “What factors affect the amount of cargo a barge can hold?”, “Why do some objects float and some objects sink?”, and “How can a ship made of steel float in the ocean?”).

CFF539F0C4194E6D9DCF82BF7C29CDCE.description: Examine the effects of forces in and on objects in fluids, includingthebuoyant force.

F29AACB3578C47C6BE6447D3CF53E30E.description: Describe situations in daily life where we see evidence that the density of substances changes naturally (e.g., molten lava as it cools, water‘turning over’at 4°C in the fall, air when mirages form) or is intentionally altered (e.g., air in a hot-air balloon, cream when it is churned and cooled).

518318B519C54842B36886530CB6AD33.description: Identify the effects of changes in temperature on the density of solids, liquids, and gases and explain the results using the particle theory of matter.

ECB2676A6E494E50A33011A6D19744FB.description: Compare the densities of common substances to the density of water and discuss practical applications that are based on differing densities.

B62C61BE9DBC4271986C35F3F0FEB5AA.description: Calculate the density of various regularly shaped materials using the formula d=m/v and using units of g/mL or g/cm³

AB791028DF0B4FDA94483D3E9E497D51.description: Interpolate or extrapolate from student-constructedgraphs of density to determine the mass or volume of a substance.

1AF2FD3C36394DEBB17F6D566488CBDC.description: Value accuracy, precision, and honesty when gatheringdata about the density of objects.

ACEAEA0336194D488EFF723123B61F45.description: Measure the mass and volume of a variety of objects,record the data in tabular form, and display the data graphically.

FD82853041644EBD80058C2FE532D7EA.description: Use instruments safely, effectively, and accurately for collecting data about the density of solids, liquids, and gases.

1E3DACDA6C7A4697AA2FBEB2F9896FDA.description: Design and carry out processes, including the water displacement method, to determine the density of various regularly shaped and irregularly shaped materials.

0DA742239F2F45EA80607A0C4CA92217.description: Illustrate the relationship between mass, volume, and density of solids, liquids, and gases using the particle theory of matter.

46CBB328BE854F60AA2F72AA6DEC9741.description: Investigate and represent the density of solids, liquids, and gases based on the particle theory of matter.

CFF01EEC3DB8455EB02F9312110ED4BD.description: Physical Science: Forces, Fluids, and Density (FD)

AE9D42A1B68E43A29C11A00F3DABBA17.description: Identify new questions and problems that arise from what was learned about electromagnetic radiation (e.g., identify issues such as how and why to protect oneself against various forms of electromagnetic radiation).

002B3AB5D012448DABE55A073705CD6B.description: Defend a position on an issue or problem, identified through personal research, related to the impact of electromagnetic radiation-based technologies on self and community.

8BEF5E1F83514384B45DE755221E4836.description: Analyze the design and function of a technology that incorporates electromagnetic radiation (e.g., microwave oven, solar cooker, sun tanning lamp, infrared heat lamp, radio, medical imaging X-ray, blacklight, UV fire detector, night vision goggles, infrared thermography, and radar) on the basis of student-identified criteria such as cost, usefulness, and impact on self, society, and the environment.

C3BD027EF8B4406E93F1FF512B52DCA0.description: Provide examples of uses of instruments that emit or detect different types of electromagnetic radiation (e.g., cordless phone, cell phone, GPS, wireless computer network, black light, X-ray photographic film, radio, and thermal imaging camera).

4058CF48AEE94AB2B3EE520B923C190F.description: Compare properties of visible light (e.g., relative energy, frequency, wavelength, and human perception) to the properties of other types of electromagnetic radiation, including infrared, ultraviolet, X-rays, microwaves, and radio waves.

B6BAA684C8314323BAE4AE2AA9232E7F.description: Describe the characteristics (i.e., wavelength, frequency, energy transferred, and typical sources) of different typesof electromagnetic radiation, including infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, microwaves, and radio waves.

71E425C8F15B402F99502AE3728FBE88.description: Evaluate the impact of electromagnetic radiationbased technologies on self and community.

6690354E043D4E208768D94149C233B1.description: Describe the operation of optical technologies that enhance human vision (e.g., contact lenses, glasses, night vision scopes, and snow goggles).

414363FE0C5C4B638FF91B7843A6C627.description: Explain how colours are produced, using both the additive and subtractive models of colour, and identify applications of the additive and subtractive models of colour in daily life, including the use of traditional dyes.

B543708F224B4D2C81824927CC96CACB.description: Explain how the human eye detects colour, anddemonstrate that the ability to perceive colour may vary from person to person.

CE532E5274864DAD96A53F6A9EBA90A0.description: Compare human vision with that of other vertebrates and invertebrates, including the function and design of the eye.

41C023EF0FE4410AA8A890608A677968.description: Compare the functional operation of the human eye to that of a camera or other optical instruments in focusing an image.

F9BF2D4B8E584A049623B6B09955E48C.description: Illustrate, using a geometrical ray diagram, how the human eye sees objects.

02F5169DBE49450592FE68F3E833EC61.description: Identify questions to investigate arising from practical problems and issues related to human vision (e.g., “How are contact lenses crafted?”, “Do humans see colour the same way?”, and “What are some problems associated with human vision?”).

6FCAC19257EC443FA69D61A1A7AA1DFA.description: Compare the nature and properties of human vision with optical devices and vision in other living organisms.

7C77E2FF7F834D56B36574DB3D1058C3.description: Provide examples of optics-related technologies that have enabled scientific research (e.g., lasers have enabledresearch in the fields of medicine and electronics; microscopes have enabled research in medicine, forensics, and microbiology; and fibre optics and the endoscope has facilitated medical research).

C76BC8572B73497F840EA265DD86CE29.description: Work collaboratively and safely with others to identifyand correct practical problems in the way a prototype of an optical device functions.

EB0FD616C7534E72BEC6C22000AC41AC.description: Use a technological problem-solving process to design and construct a prototype of an optical device to address a student-defined problem based on findings related to an understanding of geometric optics.

4A6AA544F7E14B03BD4F03C1A9997C2B.description: Draw geometric ray diagrams to illustrate how light travels within optical devices such as pin-hole cameras, single lens reflex cameras, telescopes, microscopes, and periscopes.

F2989D432F124C67842ED66D735BD2DB.description: Receive, understand, and act on the ideas of others when trying other lenses or mirror combinations to obtain various light patterns.

61A50CCAC816493481D81189949DAB68.description: Predict and verify the effects of changes in lens position on the size and location of images produced by a convex lens and/or mirror.

431374CD06B642CE946712592927B9B2.description: Investigate to determine how light interacts withconcave and convex mirrors and lenses, including the formationof real and virtual images.

4817B2EFA2474710895793EA1028132A.description: Investigate to determine how light interacts withtransparent, translucent, and opaque materials.

1F86A2E1BB2C4C4BA4F8ADA101BE08BC.description: Explore properties and applications of optics-related technologies, including concave and convex mirrors and lenses

99F91359189F4A9BB0E8A36FEAA3B12B.description: State a conclusion that explains how evidence gathered supports or refutes a prediction related to the refraction of light through media with different refractive indices.

9F0A19A1C6DB435BB7EE33901105677E.description: Predict how light will refract when passing into transparent media with different refractive indices (e.g., water, salt water, plastic, glass, and oil) and conduct an experiment to confirm or refute that prediction.

8D72E0EBA4544D9D8D7B93BF1AC5C273.description: Describe qualitatively how visible light is refracted when passing from one substance to a substance of a different refractive index.

AA5F1E4AD7E44B439A787DF014E201D5.description: Describe applications of the laws of reflection in everyday life (e.g., sun dogs, rear view mirror, magician’s tricks, and the ability to see the Moon and other non-luminous bodies).

0401C96BD76C4850ABF9C47FB9098D3C.description: Investigate characteristics and applications of specular and diffuse reflection, including the absorption of light by surfaces of different colour and made of different materials (e.g., coloured paper, white paper, aluminium foil, mirror, andwater).

17369123BAEA41289DD693BD2BF6B25D.description: Estimate and measure angles of incidence and angles of reflection of visible light and determine the quantitative relationship between the angle of incidence and the angle of reflection.

5B139A9E27ED4DFA80AF906A4DFF1556.description: Select appropriate methods and tools and use them safely when collecting data and information toinvestigate properties of visible light.

3E28A399E89940919EBBE73E48033504.description: Investigate the properties of shadows, including umbra and penumbra formation, and demonstrate how the existenceof shadows provides evidence that light travels in straightlines.

64A2ABDE46284B83A8C9AF34D7690AFA.description: Demonstrate that light is a form of energy, that light canbe separated into a visible spectrum, and that light travels in straight lines in a uniform transparent medium.

84DB57C96A8C4385BDBEE5AC02961F72.description: Classify natural and artificial sources of light as incandescence or fluorescence (includingphosphorescent, chemiluminescent, and bioluminescent).

095CA86C4B644D55A611882F6C251D08.description: Identify and describe, through experimentation, sources and properties of visible light including: rectilinear propagation, reflection and refraction.

80AA8A816E4944AF92335898338CC696.description: Suggest explanations for discrepancies in data related to variations in the heart rate, breathing rate, and/or blood pressure of the same individual during various levels of activity when an experiment is repeated.

FF272AD89D9F43DC9D541948CB61A52B.description: Design and carry out an experiment, including identifying and controlling major variables, to compare and contrast the heart rate, breathing rate, and/or blood pressure of an individual during various levels of activity.

992B2975118340909C9192AF8E57AD43.description: Select and synthesize information from various sources to illustrate examples of conflicting evidence regarding theways in which we should maintain our body (e.g., energy drinks, dairy products, vaccinations, and vitamin supplements).

621C2B30600342C5B11B80B049199731.description: Discuss personal and societal ethical issues related to the use of various technologies (e.g., pacemaker, artificial hip, prosthetic limbs, and artificial heart) that support or replace ailing body systems.

4E5DA46BC06B4364ABE194FD3FC23519.description: Predict the impact of the failure or removal of one ormore organs on the healthy functioning of the human body.

AA34C6E274FC4AAD8DE0AD141B4FA9CC.description: Analyze the impact of personal lifestyle choices (e.g., nutrition, exercise, smoking, drugs, and alcohol) on the functions and efficiency of the human respiratory, circulatory, digestive, excretory, and nervoussystems.

BED82E855DD24475AA917FBC26B4184A.description: Analyze how organ systems work together to obtain and transport nutrients and oxygen, and to remove wastesfrom the body.

A134B82F43774A0895045B88DBA0A55F.description: Provide examples of how the body reacts to internal and external stimuli such as viruses, bacteria, alcohol, drugs, dust, and temperature changes.

AF48A9BA72D248B493D73E157D62E9CF.description: Describe how various body systems work together to accomplish tasks such as eating, running, andsleeping.

6A3A10D0A6FC4E3BA8CE0E78873E3D79.description: Show interest in science-related questions and issues by posing questions and defining practical problems related to the healthy functioning of the human body.

0E5DFA22323447CFA12D28760376AE49.description: Examine First Nations and Métis perspectives on the interdependence and connectedness of human body systems and the sacredness of life.

F7D7CAE6C28C43F9AA49E2632ADF8624.description: Analyze how the interdependence of organ systems contributes to the healthy functioning of the human body.

DFFE814274174C46A2A940B0A38647A9.description: Describe examples of science- and technology-based careers in Saskatchewan that require an understanding of cells and human body systems (e.g., lab and X-ray technicians,doctors, physiotherapists, nutritionists, and public health nurses).

D5D1B2E26C384CBB8BB87CDAC1B9852A.description: Summarize the main points of modern cell theory and identify the contributions of men and women, past and present, to the development of the theory.

FAED8853842548A485327DFCC5F15CD9.description: Relate the needs and functions of various cells and organsto the needs and functions of the human organism as a whole.

F955E4173527442A8538F70A31C46B01.description: Construct a representation of the relationships among cells, tissues, organs, and organ systems in humans using examples from the respiratory, circulatory, digestive, excretory, and nervous systems.

E9A3CD97B86F4A84B998C63C5FBF9B21.description: Describe the function and provide examples of the four major types of tissue found in humans (i.e., muscle, nerve, epithelial, and connective tissue).

058DDFCBBC414CF4B96399C26E114058.description: Analyze why cells and tissues are specialized in multi-cellular organisms.

9BC89AB0CC994508A1D6DCA47E786EE9.description: Research various ideas and theories, past and present, used to explain the composition of the human body (e.g., living organisms were made of air, fire, and water; and body is animated by spirit).

C36962470A4540B29B3AB3729F221721.description: Pose questions about the composition of the human body such as “What are humans madeof?”.

B618EA8485BA458489A464890BFADF4A.description: Distinguish structural and functional relationships among cells, tissues, organs, and organ systems in humans and how this knowledge is important to various careers.

E1121AFA9342441FB9C5EDB1D16073A2.description: Show concern for self and others by safely planning and carrying out activities involving microscopes, slides, and biological material.

B6D6D31846A145E58CB94C0565A6EAB4.description: Use a microscope effectively and accurately to observe differences in structure between plant and animal cells and draw labelled diagrams of what is seen.

89D199618D164968920EAE0D8E8D6948.description: Calculate the magnification of a microscope, andestimate and determine the size of objects viewed through a microscope.

31301F647DE74789BE5BFF1DF7CFA05B.description: Prepare samples of plant and animal cells for viewing bywet mounting and staining when necessary

294884A323E2400D931372587B2DA0F7.description: Identify the parts of a compound light microscope, describe their functions, and describe how to use a compound light microscope correctly and safely.

BC50564381B8405E8C4F0CF7A169B34A.description: Demonstrate proficiency in the use of a compound light microscope to observe plant and animal cells.

99A9B40AD5A54AD2A8A4CCAB7C864C0A.description: Analyze the strengths and weaknesses of various representations of the structure and function of plant and animal cells.

BD0D930080FB416FA38F37E61A1A8AC0.description: Work cooperatively with team members to develop and carry out a plan to construct a representation (e.g., model,drawing, sculpture, or dance) of the structures and functions of plant and animal cells.

70ACB240F6A7484CA7C9791A141F4D77.description: Use appropriate scientific terminology to communicateplans, ideas, and results related to the study of plant and animal cells

2A03D2A8D71848A2A58956C8641EF57C.description: Explain the function of cell structures (e.g., cell wall, cell membrane, vacuole, nucleus, cytoplasm, mitochondria, and chloroplast), including how each structure contributes to the health of plant and animal cells.

E2D3D4E3F1B84A0EB58698AF596B3C75.description: Observe and identify cell structures (e.g., cell wall, cell membrane, vacuole, nucleus, cytoplasm, mitochondria, and chloroplast) and identify which are found in plant cells and which are found in animal cells.

B49EAF3F86BA4C73970CF7B0C5D0D450.description: Model the processes of diffusion and osmosis to demonstrate how gases and water move into and out of plant and animal cells.

380D7018550746A496F033DA507E7DC8.description: Design and carry out an experiment to demonstrate the function of selectively permeable membranes in cells.

4B8247F3E1914C9CB4EE2B0220AE8571.description: Explain how growth and reproduction of livingorganisms depends on cell division.

FCDEBEAD78CD40589708A3B04AD3063A.description: Observe and describe how single-celled organisms take in food and move.

68003AF110B64015972F26A48AA4B6EF.description: Categorize organisms as single-celled and multi-cellular.

54031BCE7EBC4694AEC2916FB69A4969.description: Explain that the cell is a living system that exhibits all the characteristics of life including growth, movement,reaction to stimulus, and reproduction.

C231345EB88B4EEA8466A2DF96CCEA1C.description: Analyze the characteristics of cells, and compare structural and functional characteristics of plant and animal cells.

3813AF6BBF674FA9870F99EA230C335C.description: Life Science: Cells, Tissues, Organs, and Systems (CS)
